title: 820-3478-A no power
message: I got a dead 820-3478-A on the bench. Tried new PSU but none of the LEDS light up. Anyone fix any of these here?

title: 820-3478-A no power
message:
Please, post usefull information!
We need some readings, like voltages, diode mode to ground...

Start with U/Q8470.

title: 820-3478-A no power
message:
Ok, U8470:

1:  12.15V
2:  3.42V
3:  N/C
4:  GND (0)
5:  3.851V
6:  21.61V
7: 12.15V
8: 12.15V

In the schematic it shows Q8470 as having 8 pins but on the board I see 4. They all measured 12.15V

title: 820-3478-A no power
message:
Looks like all is good with U6911:

1: 1.25V
2: 3.42V
3: 7.04V
4: 3.42V
5: GND
6: 12.15v
7: 0
8: 2.978V

title: 820-3478-A no power
message: So after doing some power rail testing, I found that I have a short on the PP3V3_S5 Rail.

title: 820-3478-A no power
message: Could I inject voltage to see what gets hot? Or would that be a bad idea?

title: 820-3478-A no power
message:
Which is the exact ohm value?
You can inject starting with 1V, no more than 4V...

title: 820-3478-A no power
message:
1V should be more than enough in such.
But you will need a bench power supply which can support at least 10A, better 20A.

title: 820-3478-A no power
message: Yeah unfortunately mine can only do 3A. I'm going to buy another one soon. When I inject 1V @ 3A the only thing that gets warm is the PCH....U1100

title: 820-3478-A no power
message:
If U1100 heats with 1V, no more doubts.
Always let amps at max, you can't adjust the current.
Current sinked by the board is accordingly with injected voltage and internal resistance of the short to ground...

title: 820-3478-A no power
message: gotcha, yeah I am not limiting the current, my PSU has the option to turn off over current protection and overvoltage protection. I took it back to customer and told them to replace the board. It would have been nice if my PSU could go up to 10A, I would have loved to see the PCH get red hot!

title: 820-3478-A no power
message:
You can arm a DPS5020
[url]https://www.ebay.es/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=m570.l1313&_nkw=dps5020&_sacat=0[/url]

or something like this
[url]https://www.ebay.es/itm/480W-power-supply-Adjustable-Current-limit-12V-24V-36V-48V-60V-80V-120V-220V-DC/264278771163?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=563854956982&_trksid=p2060353.m1438.l2649[/url]

24V/20A can be used to power the boards for test too, apart of injecting voltage.
12V/40A is more for injecting voltage only...

title: 820-3478-A no power
message: Ok, cool. I'll look into that.
